SBSE Collection Employees and all Operating Divisions

) The Internal Revenue Service in certain circumstances obtains a judgment against a taxpayer or third party when collection enforcement actions alone and cannot resolve the case. The Department of Justice (DOJ) maintains tion of these judgments and is responsible for collection. The Advisory organization maintains controls for these cases internally and coordinates Department of Justice (DOJ) on assistance they may require. Advisory is responsible to coordinate with Counsel and other internal organizations with work in connection to these cases including requests for enforcement (

) Purpose: This section provides the procedural instructions for collection coordinating with DOJ or Counsel while a case is under DOJ control, judgment monitoring, and resolving judgments after the DOJ has returned control of the case to the IRS. Note: A case is always under DOJ “control” once it has been referred to the in the particular sense that, without the knowledge and consent of the Tax Division, the IRS should not compromise a liability that is included in a judgment unless the Tax Division approves the compromise (

) Audience: Collection employees responding to requests for assistance DOJ and speciﬁcally Advisory staff use this IRM in assisting DOJ or coordinating responses, and resolving cases after control returns to the (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy. (
) Program Owner: The program owner is Collection, an organization within Small Business Self-Employed (SBSE) division. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are Chief Counsel, DOJ Division Civil Trial Sections, DOJ Tax Division’s Financial Litigation Unit and other DOJ attorneys. (
) Program Goals: The goal of the program aligns with (i) IRS Strategic Goal II— to effectively enforce the law to ensure compliance with tax and combat fraud, and (ii) Objective
— to enforce domestic and compliance by strengthening expertise, adopting innovative approaches, streamlining procedures. (

) The provisions of this section apply in general to all judgment cases by Advisory. Judgments entered in a civil tax case may be for assessed tax liabilities or for liabilities that cannot be assessed (i.e., unassessable Required actions are to be taken by Advisory unless otherwise noted. (

) Deﬁnition Assessed Liability: Suits to reduce tax assessments to will result in a judgment being entered against the taxpayer against whom assessments were made for the entire amount of the outstanding tax (see also IRM
, Additional Procedures for Judgments for Liabilities). (
) Deﬁnition Unassessable Liability: Suits brought against taxpayers or third parties resulting in money judgments where there is no underlying tax (see also IRM
, Additional Procedures for Judgments for able Liabilities). For example: • suit to recover an erroneous refund, (
) Internal Revenue Manual

A case is always under DOJ “control” once it has been referred to the DOJ, in the particular sense that, without the knowledge and consent of the Tax Division, the IRS should not compromise a liability that is included in a judgment unless the Tax Division approves the compromise
suit to recover an erroneous refund,
suit to collect unpaid employment taxes under IRC

(b), and suit in which restitution amounts that cannot be assessed as taxes are ordered payable to the IRS.
the Tax Division or a US Attorney’s Office), DOJ has settlement authority (IRC

, Compromises). The IRS has no authority to settle these cases. Depending upon the nature of the action, the litigation may be handled by either a civil trial attorney in the Tax Division or an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the local U.S. Attorney’s Office. Any actions taken in litigation cases must be coordinated through the Area Counsel Attorney assigned to the case unless the case is of the type that may be handled solely by the local U.S. Attorney’s Office.

Example: Certain types of cases that are brought against the IRS under section 28 USC 2410, (e.g., foreclosure, quiet title, condemnation, interpleader), will also be assigned to an Area Counsel Attorney.

Program Reports: Suits are speciﬁc to the case or case combination at hand. They vary in type and scope. Advisors are required to monitor their ongoing litigation and open judgment cases annually and more frequently if appropriate. There are several reporting tools assisting advisors with this task and they notate the status in the Integrated Collection System (ICS) history.

Program Effectiveness: Whenever litigation involving collection matters is pending, ongoing, or liabilities are reduced to judgment, advisors are respon
sible for coordination with stakeholders, maintaining appropriate internal case controls, and monitoring outcomes. Advisory responds to requests for assis
tance and queries from Counsel and DOJ.

Counsel Throughout this IRM section, the term “Counsel” will refer to either the Area Counsel Attorney assigned to the case or the local Assistant U.S. Attorney, if the case is being handled solely by that office. ) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, see irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights, Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR). (
) When a tax assessment is reduced to judgment, the federal tax lien under IRC

does not merge into the judgment, but continues to exist for pendently. Therefore, when assessed tax liabilities are reduced to on the Government has two different collection avenues available: a. The assessed tax liabilities may be collected by levy under the Revenue Code, or b. The judgment and judgment lien may be enforced judicially under law and under the Federal Debt Collection Procedures Act (FDCPA). Reminder: Unassessable Liabilities: When there is no underlying tax liability a judgment, there is no IRC
statutory federal tax lien to The judgment stands on its own, is not reﬂected on IDRS, and
For procedural guidelines on recommending, working, and responding to suits and claims for damages both for and against the United States, see:

When a tax assessment is reduced to judgment, the federal tax lien created under IRC 6321 does not merge into the judgment, but continues to exist inde- pendently. Therefore, when assessed tax liabilities are reduced to judgment, the Government has two different collection avenues available:

Unassessable Liabilities: When there is no underlying tax liability for a judgment, there is no IRC 6321 statutory federal tax lien to protect. The judgment stands on its own, is not reﬂected on IDRS, and cannot be collected by the IRS. See IRM 25.3.5.4.3, Additional Procedures for Judgments for Unassessable Liabilities.
be collected by the IRS. See IRM
, Additional Procedures Judgments for Unassessable Liabilities. (

) Because the federal tax lien does not merge with the judgment lien, the periods applicable to collect and / or renew ﬁlings for judgment liens are different from the federal tax lien. a. Judgment and Judgment Lien: While the judgment itself is not to limitation and can be enforceable at any time, normally the lien collection period is twenty years. A judgment lien can also be renewed once for an additional

years with the approval of a court. However, judgment liens only attach to the real property of a judgment debtor when a certiﬁed copy of an abstract of judgment is ﬁled in the same manner as a NFTL. b. Federal Tax Liability and Federal Tax Lien: The original federal tax liability and federal tax lien collection period is ten years. IRC
(a) provides for the extension of the collection statute expiration date (CSED), where a suit is timely ﬁled to reduce tax assessments to
Because the federal tax lien does not merge with the judgment lien, the time periods applicable to collect and / or renew ﬁlings for judgment liens are different from the federal tax lien.
judgment. This means it is imperative that ﬁled Notices of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) be reﬁled timely in accordance with IRC

(g) in order to preserve the federal tax lien’s priority. Consequently, with a judgment, IRS may pursue administrative collection action, indeﬁnitely, against the taxpayer’s real or personal property. Thus, the CSED for collecting the liability is extended until the tax liability (or the judgment) is satisﬁed or becomes unenforceable.
becomes unenforceable. Note: See IRM

, Notice of Lien Reﬁling for details on reﬁling NFTL. Caution: It is equally important to ensure that the liens do not release during the pendency of the litigation. The pending suit does not prevent release of lien if a self-releasing NFTL has been ﬁled. Accordingly, NFTLs must be timely reﬁled during the pendency of litigation to prevent release of the lien. (
) Although the collection statute is extended indeﬁnitely under IRC
(a) a timely suit to reduce assessments to judgment is ﬁled and the judgment is obtained, the case will remain in active status only as long as there is collec- tion potential (See IRM
), Closing Action, Procedures). (
) Primary responsibility for the initial collection of judgments entered in favor of the United States rests with the DOJ. The DOJ may request advice and tance from the IRS. See IRM
, Collection of Judgments, for a general discussion of the legal aspects of judgment collection. (

) After the judgment has been entered, or a settlement is reached, the DOJ Section sometimes transfers the case to the Tax Division FLU, which then becomes responsible for attempting to collect the judgment. In other the DOJ Trial Section attempts collection. When DOJ collection efforts are exhausted, it will prepare the case for closing and transfer back to the IRS. At this point, collection jurisdiction is generally returned to the IRS. However, diction to compromise a judgment is retained by DOJ. (
) Advisory is responsible for controlling judgments by: a. Securing a copy of the judgment and uploading it to
pproval. b. Updating both ICS and
pproval controls. c. Monitoring and following up as appropriate, but at least annually, on all active judgments for assessed and unassessable liabilities. (
) Monitoring Offer in Compromise (MOIC) units have responsibility for taxpayers’ compliance with settlements in judgment cases requiring future actions. See IRM
, Responsibilities. (

) Revenue officers may be called upon to assist in collecting judgments and ducting follow-up investigations. Involvement may be in the form of courtesy investigations initiated by Advisory or direct Bal Due case assignments.
Note: See IRM 5.12.8, Notice of Lien Reﬁling for details on reﬁling NFTL.
Caution: It is equally important to ensure that the liens do not release during the pendency of the litigation. The pending suit does not prevent release of a lien if a self
releasing NFTL has been ﬁled. Accordingly, NFTLs must be timely reﬁled during the pendency of litigation to prevent release of the lien.

After the judgment has been entered, or a settlement is reached, the DOJ Trial Section sometimes transfers the case to the Tax Division FLU, which then becomes responsible for attempting to collect the judgment. In other instances, the DOJ Trial Section attempts collection. When DOJ collection efforts are exhausted, it will prepare the case for closing and transfer back to the IRS. At this point, collection jurisdiction is generally returned to the IRS. However, juris- diction to compromise a judgment is retained by DOJ.
(1) After DOJ obtains a judgment, the advisor’s case controls change.

(6) Actions When the Judgment Debtor Relocates: If it is determined that the judgment debtor has relocated to another state or federal judicial district, the advisor assigned to the case will take the follow actions:
When the Judgment Debtor Relocates: If it is determined that debtor has relocated to another state or federal judicial district, the assigned to the case will take the follow actions:
) DOJ retains jurisdiction for collection of active judgments. Do not close the ICS control (NFOI
) or discontinue monitoring / follow-ups as long as diction remains with DOJ. (
) Occasionally, the advisor will request revenue officer assistance in a case. Generally, this will not occur on judgments less than the criteria in IRM Revenue
), Criteria for Bringing Suit. (

) When assistance is needed, and after the advisor has exhausted all internal sources, the advisor will issue an Other Investigation (OI) to the Field Collection group manager’s hold ﬁle for the zip code where the tasks need to be completed. Generally, the advisor will contact the receiving group to explain the request and speciﬁc actions needed. This may include identify- ing assets through public records research or any other type of asset veriﬁcation deemed necessary. (
) When a judgment involving assessed liabilities is no longer in active status, a Bal Due case may be assigned to a revenue officer if case selection criteria are met.

Once a judgment is entered in a case where assessments were reduced to judgment, request input of Transaction Code (TC) 550, deﬁner code 4, using 20 years from the date the judgment was entered as the new extension date. This action will extend the CSED on IDRS for 20 years and prevent a TC 608 from being generated automatically and zeroing out the tax module.

While the timely ﬁling of a suit to reduce assessments to judgment will extend the CSED indeﬁnitely, the IRS has decided that if there is no collec- tion potential with respect to the assessments reduced to judgment, the judgment will not be maintained on IDRS after
years from the date of the entry of the judgment. However, if collection sources are identiﬁed after this
year period, the account may be reinstated and collection actions resumed. (See IRM
), Closing Action, Procedures).
Reversals (TC

) While the judgment control is active, ensure that all applicable Notices of Federal Tax Lien (NFTLs) are properly reﬁled. Determine the required reﬁling period and establish ICS controls to follow-up. See IRM
, Reﬁling Period. Note: Because the federal tax lien does NOT merge into the judgment lien, and NFTLs ﬁled after

contain self-releasing provisions which extinguish the tax lien if the notice is not reﬁled, the NFTL must be timely reﬁled in order to preserve the federal tax lien and maintain the IRS’s priority If the NFTL is not timely reﬁled, the tax lien will be extinguished and actions will need to be taken to revoke the release and reinstate the lien in order to take administrative collection action. See IRM
, Revocation of Lien Release, and IRM
, Reinstating the Statutory Lien. (
) After DOJ advises the IRS (through counsel) that their efforts to collect the judgment have ended, and all terms of applicable settlement agreements been met, request input of TC
If no information relating to the collection the ﬁnal judgment is provided by DOJ within

months from the judgment date, contact the Tax Division attorney or the FLU of the local U.S. Attorney’s office if the case was handled by that office, to determine what, if any, actions are being taken by DOJ to collect the judgment. If DOJ has determined that there is no current collection potential and that it will, or has, closed its case, request written notiﬁcation that DOJ is closing its case and jurisdiction is transferred back to the IRS. When the case is referred to the IRS for collec- tion, the TC
should be reversed to allow the case to be put back into the collection stream. Note: Do not request input of TC
or close the Advisory ICS judgment control

While the judgment control is active, ensure that all applicable Notices of Federal Tax Lien (NFTLs) are properly reﬁled. Determine the required reﬁling period and establish ICS controls to follow-up. See IRM
, Reﬁling Period.

If DOJ has determined that there is no current collection potential and that it will, or has, closed its case, request written notiﬁcation that DOJ is closing its case and jurisdiction is being transferred back to the IRS. should be reversed to allow the case to be put back into the collection stream.

) In cases where a judgment is obtained for unassessable liabilities, it is important to ensure that a certiﬁed copy of the abstract of judgment is ﬁled Procedures order to create a judgment lien against the judgment debtor’s real property. for Secure a copy of the abstract and upload it to
pproval. Liabilities (

) The IRS may not take administrative collection action under the provisions the Internal Revenue Code against the judgment debtor to collect the if there is no underlying tax assessment or federal tax lien. Instead, collection actions must be taken under state law or under the Federal Debt Collection Procedures Act (FDCPA) by the Tax Division or the local U.S. ney’s Office (i.e., Tax Division FLU or the local U.S. Attorney Office’s FLU). See also IRM
, Effect of Judgment on Collection Statute of tions. (

) While administrative collection action may not be taken to collect a for most unassessable liabilities, with the exception of offsetting tax the advisor is responsible for coordinating with either the Tax Division or local U.S. Attorney’s Office, depending upon which office is handling the to ensure the availability of assistance in conducting investigations using all available internal sources to determine if resources exist for satisfying the judgment. (

) In appropriate cases, the advisor will issue an OI (Other Investigation) to collection to assist in locating assets to satisfy the judgment. This may identifying assets through public records research, or any other type of veriﬁcation deemed necessary. (
) If assets are located that can be seized in satisfaction of the judgment, this information should immediately be communicated to the appropriate DOJ component. (
) The advisor will also take the appropriate steps to ensure that any tax refunds of those named in the judgment are offset to the unassessed judgment. (

) In cases where there is collection potential, the advisor will follow-up with DOJ at a minimum of annually to determine the status of efforts to collect judgment. Circumstances may warrant more frequent case activity. (
) Cases may not be removed from active follow-up status and the NF OI for the judgment case may not be closed as long as the case remains with DOJ. See also IRM
, Closing Actions. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) See IRM
, Restitution, for information relating to court orders the taxpayer to pay restitution to the IRS in criminal cases. (

) The United States, like any other party to litigation, is entitled to an award of costs when it prevails in an action. Costs that may be awarded include fees court reporters, fees for witnesses, and the fees of the U.S. Marshal for of summonses and subpoenas. (
) Under IRC

(b), Sanctions and costs awarded by courts, the IRS may assess and, upon notice and demand, collect (in the same manner as a tax) any monetary sanctions, penalties or costs awarded by the court to the States. See IRM
, Assessment of Court Sanctions, Penalties, and Costs, for further discussion of this provision. Note: IRC
(a) Tax Court sanctions and costs are not included under IRC
) Requests for assessment under IRC

(b) will generally come from the DOJ. These requests must include a copy of the court order providing for award of monetary sanctions, penalties or costs to the IRS. DOJ will send request to the Area Counsel attorney assigned to the case for appropriate routing within the IRS. In collection cases handled by Advisory, a request for an IRC
(b) assessment will be routed by the Area Counsel attorney to advisor assigned to the case. (
) Form
, Assessment and Abatement of Miscellaneous Civil Penalties, is used to request assessments under IRC
(b). If possible, the advisor assigned to the case will complete the Form
within

calendar days receiving a request for assessment, a copy of the court order, and any addi- tional information that may be needed. Note: While there is no Assessment Statute Expiration Date (ASED) for an ment made pursuant to IRC

(b), an assessment must be made administrative collection actions (e.g., ﬁling a Notice of Federal Tax Lien or issuing a levy) can be taken by the IRS to collect this amount. The for assessment therefore should be handled promptly. (

of Form

I, Miscellaneous Penalties. a. For the Year in Item

(b) assessments. c. Provide the amount to be assessed on page

) The United States, like any other party to litigation, is entitled to an award of costs when it prevails in an action. Costs that may be awarded include fees of court reporters, fees for witnesses, and the fees of the U.S. Marshal for service of summonses and subpoenas. (
) Under IRC

(b), Sanctions and costs awarded by courts, the IRS may assess and, upon notice and demand, collect (in the same manner as a tax) any monetary sanctions, penalties or costs awarded by the court to the United States. See IRM
, Assessment of Court Sanctions, Penalties, and Costs, for further discussion of this provision.

Requests for assessment under IRC

(b) will generally come from the DOJ. These requests must include a copy of the court order providing for award of monetary sanctions, penalties or costs to the IRS. DOJ will send request to the Area Counsel attorney assigned to the case for appropriate routing within the IRS. In collection cases handled by Advisory, a request for an IRC

Note: While there is no Assessment Statute Expiration Date (ASED) for an ment made pursuant to IRC

(b), an assessment must be made before administrative collection actions (e.g., ﬁling a Notice of Federal Tax Lien or issuing a levy) can be taken by the IRS to collect this amount. The request for assessment therefore should be handled promptly.
Note: If using the bookmarks for the form, go to 9.I, Miscellaneous Penalties.

) An assessment made under IRC

(b) may be collected, upon notice and demand, as a tax. The normal ten-year Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED), plus any applicable extension/suspension, applies with respect to administrative collection action (e.g., ﬁling a Notice of Federal Tax Lien or issuing a levy) that may be taken to collect the assessment. If a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) is ﬁled with respect to the IRC assessment, the date the statutory tax lien arises under IRC
is the date of the IRC
(b) assessment, and the NFTL reﬁling period under IRC

(g) is calculated using that date. If other previously assessed tax liabilities were reduced to judgment in the same court proceeding, procedures for extending the CSED for these other assessments should be followed. See IRM

, Additional Procedures for Judgments for Assessed Liabilities, above. Note: Because a judgment was entered in the amount awarded as monetary sanctions, penalties or costs, the procedures of the Federal Debt Procedures Act (FDCPA) will also apply with respect to collecting the of the IRC
(b) assessment. If collection potential is anticipated beyond the ten-year period under IRC
from the date of the IRC
(g) as- sessment, plus any applicable extension/suspension, contact Area Counsel to determine whether collection actions should be taken under the FDCPA collect this amount. (

When a judgment case for assessed tax liabilities is closed by DOJ and ferred back to the IRS, use the procedures in the table below as well as any applicable procedures in IRM 25.3.6.5.5 , Other Closing Actions.
) The Records Control Schedule (RSC) for Collection is located in Document
, Records and Information Management Records Control Schedules, Schedule
The RSC provides mandatory instructions for retaining and and disposing of records no longer needed for current business. (
) Active judgment ﬁles should be retained by Advisory until they become inactive. See Document
, Records and Information Management Records Control Schedules, Schedule
, Item
(a). The ICS judgment control module(s) remain(s) open, as long as a judgment remains active. (

) Once the judgment becomes inactive, the related ICS judgment control is closed. Inactive judgment ﬁles should be retired to the Federal Records Center three years after being placed in inactive judgment ﬁles.. For information on retiring records to the Federal Records Center, see Document
, Records and Information Management Records Control Schedules, Schedule
, Item
) In cases where the judgment has been fully satisﬁed, the judgment ﬁle should be destroyed two years after the judgment is satisﬁed. See Document
, Records and Information Management Records Control Schedules, Schedule
, Item
(c), Satisﬁed Judgment Files.

The Records Control Schedule (RSC) for Collection is located in Document 12990, Records and Information Management Records Control Schedules, Schedule 28. The RSC provides mandatory instructions for retaining and disposing of records no longer needed for current business.

Active judgment ﬁles should be retained by Advisory until they become inactive. See Document 12990, Records and Information Management Records Control Schedules, Schedule 28, Item 53(a). The ICS judgment control module(s) remain(s) open, as long as a judgment remains active.
